answers.answer: It is unusual to see undectable TSH at this point - there are cases where it takes more than one year, but if T4 and T3 have been normal for several months, the TSH usually comes up.  Would talk to your endo about pituitary testing to confirm we can "trust" the TSH -- if normal, then would treat as subclinical hyperthyroidism and increase methimazole to normalize TSH.  If your resting heart-rate is normal (60-80s for most people) and you have not heart disease, beta blockers aren't mandatory.  Bone loss is more common in post-menopausal women, so this may be a concern - would take calcium and vit D.

Thank you for your answer - I just want to make sure I understand you right. Is testing pituitary mean checking FSH, LH, prolactin?  Also, what is meant by heart disease?  My Echo was normal, no HTN, no diabetes, but I have short runs of atrial tachycardia and sinus tachycardia on holter. Would this be heart disease or no?Thank you so much for your help.
If you're having episodes of tachycardia, then I think the beta blocker would be reasonable.  Discuss this with your cardiologist.  Yes, the labs you mention are part of the pituitary testing.

question: Dear Dr. lupo,  I have Grave's disease and have been on Methimazole x 18 months. My free T4 has been normal for 17 months and has been 0.97 to 1.20 for the past 6 months yet my TSH is still undetectable.  My free T3 is also normal.I had no nodules. Can this hurt my heart or cause osteoporosis?  Do I need any beta blockers to prevent cardiac damage or arrythmias?  I do not have symptoms but havE gained 8 # in the past 6 months andAlso, I am 47 and abruptly stopped periods about a year ago.Any other thoughts?  Thank you so much.
title: Undetectable TSH after 18 months on tapazole
